steps.section: Purification of PCR products by AMPure beads
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1vgj3","text":"PCR products should be purified from free primers, nucleotides and primer dimer species.This step uses AMPure XP beads. This purification systems utilize Agencourt’s solid-phase paramagnetic bead technology for high-throughput purification of PCR amplicons and an optimized buffer to selectively bind PCR amplicons 100bp and larger to paramagnetic beads. Excess primers, nucleotides, salts, and enzymes can be then removed by a washing procedure. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4maod","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8pl9","text":"For more details please look: AMPure beads/technical.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":30,"length":23}],"data":{}},{"key":"5tagr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9rrm","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4hlpn","text":"Protocol for 96 Well Format using DNA hood:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":43}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7oqd0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20lm3","text":"Before starting:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6437h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1i240","text":"- Fresh 70% ethanol should be prepared for optimal results (35ml of ethanol and 15ml of nuclease free water).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3e0q","text":"The ethanol and the water should be molecular grade.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6dqlp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"46ih6","text":"- 10mM TRIS pH 8.0 (molecular grade) for DNA elution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6f55","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vds9","text":"- Determine whether or not a plate transfer is necessary. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6angt","text":"Aspirate out the ethanol using an multichannel pipette and discard. Remove all of the ethanol from the bottom of the well. The same tips can be use twice with the same sample  to  completely aspirate the ethanol. It is important that to pass the tips by a kimwipes between the aspiration to avoid carry over of ethanol. Change the kimwipes and NEVER touch where the previous samples have touched and left ethanol. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f8tkf","text":"Despite the fact that some protocols indicate that the beads can be let to dry, in our experience, after the beads are dried (the beads are dry when the bead ring appears cracked), it is very hard to recover the purified material leading to a significantly decrease in the elution efficiency. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":293}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"l1r3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"368fd","text":"7. Remove the reaction plate from the magnet plate and add 40 μL of 10mM TRIS pH 8.0 to each well of the reaction plate and pipette mix 10 times. {"blocks":[{"key":"d4s95","text":"Sequencing by synthesis method: https://youtu.be/fCd6B5HRaZ8","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":32,"length":28}],"data":{}},{"key":"f1hpb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pkjg","text":"In  principle, the concept behind NGS technology is similar to Sanger sequencing. DNA polymerase catalyzes the incorporation of fluorescently labelled deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs) into a DNA template strand during sequential cycles of DNA synthesis. During each cycle, at the point of incorporation, the nucleotides are identified by fluorophore excitation. The critical difference is that, instead of sequencing a single DNA fragment, NGS extends this process across millions of fragments in a massively parallel fashion. The sequencing by Illumina technology involves tree basic steps:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4c5l2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vuf3","text":"1. Library preparation:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nupd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fm3v4","text":"When working with genomes, metagenomes or transcriptomes for example, this step involves the random fragmentation of the DNA or cDNA sample followed by selection of fragment size and 5′ and 3′ adapter ligation. In this case, the library preparation products as well as the protocols are different. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e9e13","text":"For metabarcoding purpose, this step involves the amplification by PCR of a given gene region (for example V4 or V9 region of 18S rRNA gene) or gene itself if its size does not exceed 600bp (the longest fragment size that can be sequenced by Illumina technology). The defined forward and reverse primers that are complementary upstream and downstream of the region of interest, needs to be designed with overhang adapters which will be use in a subsequent limited‐cycle amplification step, in order to add the dual‐index barcodes and Illumina flowcell adapters. Samples are normalized by equal concentration, pooled (more details of these steps below), and sequenced on the MiSeq (Figure 3A).The final fragment contains the flow cell adapters (P5 and P7), barcodes indices (i5 and i7) and the adapter region for the  sequencing step (adapter) (Figure 3B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":680,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":843,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"clh6u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8cjc8","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d5btv","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fve0f","text":" 2. Cluster generation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ea872","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pvo0","text":"For cluster generation, the denaturated library is loaded into the flow cell where fragments are captured on a lawn of surface-bound oligos complementary to the library adapters (P5 and P7). Each fragment is then  amplified into distinct, clonal clusters through bridge amplification. When cluster generation is complete, all fragments attached to P7 sites are cleaved off,  leaving only fragments attached to the P5 sites. The sequencing processcan then start. For Illumina sequencing platform, Cluster density is a critically important metric that impacts run quality, reads passing filter and total data output. Under clustering generates high data quality however it results in lower data output. Alternatively, over clustering can lead to poor run performance, lower Q30 scores, the possible introduction of sequencing artifacts, and lower total data output since the majority of data can be with low Q30 score. Performing a  run at optimal cluster density involves finding a balance between under-and over clustering. The goalis to sequence  at high enough densities to maximize total  data output,  while  maintaining low enough densities toavoid the negative effects of over clustering.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"epfeo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edvbq","text":"•How does over clustering affect Sequencing Data?","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"84ufs","text":"(this part has been adapted from the document: support.illumina/miseq-overclustering-primer.pdf)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":47,"length":48}],"data":{}},{"key":"7uank","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ivhn","text":"I. Lower Q30 Scores — Due to overloaded signal intensities, the ratio of base intensity to background for each base is  decreased. This decrease often results in ambiguity during base calling and leads to a decrease in data quality.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":2,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkghq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"66t42","text":"II. Lower Clusters Passing Filter — The percentage of clusters passing filter (%PF) is an indication of signal purity from each cluster. Over clustered flow cells typically have higher numbers of overlapping clusters. This leads to poor template generation, which then causes a decrease in the %PF metric.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7s08f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16mk9","text":"III. Lower Data Output — Reduced yield (gigabases [Gb] per flow cell) is a by product of lower %PF.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":5,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8mnui","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7g7oq","text":"IV. Inaccurate Demultiplexing — Index reads usually have low diversity by design, which can lead to poor base calling. Over clustering exacerbates the potential for poor base calling, which in turn, can lead to demultiplexing failures.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4f39","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"buo6l","text":"V. Complete Run Failure — In cases of extreme over clustering, focusing can fail and the run may terminate at any cycle.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rbef","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"208um","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dmub","text":" 3. sequencing","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":1,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9kqlk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ki6m","text":"Illumina SBS (Sequencing by synthesis) technology uses a proprietary reversible terminator – based method that  detects single bases as they are incorporated into DNA emplate strands. As all four-reversible terminator – bound dNTPs are present during each sequencing cycle, natural competition minimizes incorporation bias and greatly reduces raw error rates compared to other technologies. The result is highly accurate base-by-base sequencing that virtually eliminates sequence context – specific errors, even within repetitive sequence regions and homopolymers. The sequencing primers anneal to the adapter region and sequence the DNA fragment from the adapter. Then a second sequencing primer will sequence the opposite direction from the adapter, namely the index. Just one base is added to the sequence in each cycle. Each cycle the flow cell is flushed with a mix of all four fluorescent bases. The bases are reversibly terminated to ensure the incorporation of only one base per cycle and unincorporated bases are washed away. Then the fluorescence of the incorporated bases is recorded. Each cluster of clonally amplified DNA  fragments,  will  show one  base. After imaging,  the fluorophore is cleaved there by eliminating fluorescence, the terminator is subsequently removed, and the cycle is repeated. We use the paired-end sequencing method. This means that instead of sequencing 300 consecutive nucleotides in one direction, 150 nucleotides are sequenced from both ends of the fragment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ll2c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2p5ff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"AD56EFE0F35F11EA9E27CD18C2F0BD00","url":"https://youtu.be/fCd6B5HRaZ8"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"BD4E92A0F35E11EA9E27CD18C2F0BD00","height":416,"id":241869,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6fs8p","text":"Figure 3: Metabarcoding steps a priori sequencing.   ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eg292","text":"(A) PCR amplification using specific primers which are designed with overhang adapters (index barcodes and Illumina flowcell adapters).   ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"eojg8","text":"(B) Final fragment with flow cell adapters (P5 and P7), barcodes indices (i5 and i7) and the adapter region for the  sequencing step (adapter). ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/74c8ab47edabda576cff2a9e74c9a44e54793fe1ada5d629a38e12e2539cda14/cj2tg6iw.png","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hngpg6iw.jpg","type":1,"webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hngng6iw.webp","width":422}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"2733FD30F36011EA9E27CD18C2F0BD00","url":"https://support.illumina.com/content/dam/illumina-marketing/documents/products/other/miseq-overclustering-primer-770-2014-038.pdf"}},"3":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"59AE0243F28511EA92F30A58A9FEAC2A","height":287.80727272727273,"id":241871,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8c57r","text":"Figure 4: Cluster formation.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/74c8ab47edabda576cff2a9e74c9a44e54793fe1ada5d629a38e12e2539cda14/cjw3g6iw.png","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hngrg6iw.jpg","type":1,"webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hngqg6iw.webp","width":482.6036585365853}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1c1t6","text":"1. Order the primers","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bi8ii","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"46ch5","text":"Use existing primers or design your own custom gene primers with the proper Illumina indices and Nextera adaptor orientations (Primers_Illumina_1.0.xlsx in attached document).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"573og","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"593eg","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f0h2g","text":"     ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4d7tp","text":"It is recommended to order the primers with a good synthesis and purity parameters. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"47imp","text":"We have order at EUROGENTEC the primers with RP-HPLC purity method, 10 or 40nmol synthesis scale and at 100µM TE concentration. We could also order in dried and dissolve them with nuclease free water or TE buffer to obtain 100µM stock solution (as described on the Eurogentec’s technical data sheet).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"47it","text":"Then we dilute them to 10 μM working concentration (1/10th the typical 100 μM working stock concentration for primers). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"230le","text":"This proceed should be perform at the PCR hood and with molecular grade water.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f49lv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"663fb","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"74bo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jddg","text":"2. Acid nucleic extraction and quantification","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6q5cl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8t07q","text":"Extract DNAs/RNA from the samples using the method/kit appropriate to the specific samples. By working with RNA, another step to transform the RNA in cDNA is necessary. Quantify and quality-check the final DNA via NanoDrop or Qubit/PicoGreen. The A280/260 ratios should be 1.8 or higher and once working with total community extracted DNAs, a concentration of at least 1 ng/μL is desirable to get consistent PCR results. Avoid secondary extractions or clean-ups for inhibitors, until PCRs have truly shown inhibition (example after trying the PCRs by diluting the original DNA and/or adding BSA to the final PCR reaction) – many suboptimal DNAs will still work in PCR. A gel can be run to verify integrity of the extracted material, but it is generally unnecessary for PCR-only studies. Some protocols suggest the normalization of the DNA samples concentration prior to the PCR. In our experience, this is not always possible given the low concentration of some samples. The volume of sample added to the PCR can be settled in function of a range of concentrations instead of normalizing all the samples to the same concentration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdqth","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5lqkl","text":"Load in agarose gel 0.8%, 1μl DNA + loading buffer. The limited of DNA detection using EtBr gels is around 10ng.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5g8et","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbq77","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ch6bs","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d86t3","text":"Sorted populations by flow cytometer can be used as an input for the PCR reactions. Photosynthetic pico and nanoeukaryotes populations selected based on light scatter, orange phycoerythrin and red chlorophyll fluorescence are sorted in sterile eppendorf tubes containing Tris-EDTA lysis buffer (Tris 10mM, EDTA 1mM and Triton x-100 1.2%).The Tris, EDTA and Nuclease-Free water use should be molecular grade. A buffer containing Tris-HCl 10mM, pH 8.0 and NaCl 20mM and filtered at 0.22 μm should be used as sheath liquid for marine samples. Sheath fluid samples should be collected and analyzed as negative controls in all subsequent steps including sequencing, in order to test for contamination in the flow sorting process. After the sorting, samples can be stored at -80C. The DNA from sorted cells can be extracted by three cycles of freezing in liquid nitrogen and thawing in {"blocks":[{"key":"3dc6j","text":"The LabChip GX  assays are based on traditional  gel electrophoresis principles that have been transferred to a chip format. The chip format dramatically reduces separation time and provides automated sizing and quantitation information in a digital format.It has the same principle as the bioanalyzer, however 96 samples can be run within 2 hours with the labchip and for a low cost when compared to the bioanalyzer. The chip contains an interconnected set of microchannels that join the separation channel and buffer wells. One of the microchannels is connected to a short capillary that extends from the bottom of the chip at a 90-degree angle. The capillary sips sample from the wells of a microplate during the assay. The following protocol can be use with either the DNA 5K (Supplemental material 1) or  DNA HS kits (Supplemental material  2). In our experience to obtain reliable concentrations, the concentration range  per fragment of each kit should be respect. Prepare Gel-Dye by adding 13 μL DNA Dye Concentrate (blue cap) to 1 vial of DNA Gel Matrix (red cap). Vortex and transfer mixture into two spin filters (approximately 550 μL per spin filter). Centrifuge at 9200 rcf for 10 minutes at room temperature. Ensure that all of the gel has passed through the filter and then discard the filter. The Gel-Dye can be stored for up to 3 weeks in the dark at 4°C. Please check for available gel matrix with dye at the platform. steps.section: Perform a Post-Run Wash WITHOUT template line wash
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4ggsc","text":"For more details, please follow the instruction at miseq-system-guide #15027617 / chap.3 sequencing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":51,"length":48}],"data":{}},{"key":"2msfm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ae89","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8i68d","text":"Always perform an instrument wash after completing a run.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ejkd","text":"Follow the software prompts to load the wash components and perform the wash.The post-run wash takes approximately 20 minutes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":81,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9o5q9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5egv","text":"Leave the used flowcell on the instrument. A flowcell must be loaded on the instrument to perform an instrument wash.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cjlcq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7mrds","text":"1. Prepare fresh wash solution with Tween 20 and laboratory-grade water:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edv83","text":"a. Add 5 ml 100% Tween 20 to 45 ml laboratory-grade water. These volumes result in 10% Tween 20.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8m9rd","text":"b. Add 25 ml 10% Tween 20 to 475 ml laboratory-grade water. Invert 5 times to mix.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3om0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f823l","text":"2. Prepare the wash components with fresh wash solution:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7p1f9","text":"a. Add 6 ml wash solution to each reservoir of the wash tray.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkl34","text":"b. Add 350 ml wash solution to the 500 ml wash bottle.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bu6ds","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ff78i","text":"3.
